I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan to the Republic of Indonesia, (ii) proposed administration of a loan to be provided by 
Agence Française de Développement (AFD) to the Republic of Indonesia, and (iii) proposed 
administration of a grant to be provided by the Multi-Donor Clean Energy Fund1 under the Clean 
Energy Financing Partnership Facility to  PT (Persero) Perusahaan Listrik Negara (PLN);2 all for 
the West Kalimantan Power Grid Strengthening Project.3  
 
2.  The project will strengthen the power grid of West Kalimantan by building new power 
transmission lines, distribution lines, and associated substations. A 145-kilometer (km) new 
distribution line, distribution feeder extensions, and a new substation will improve the reliability 
of power supply in West Kalimantan. An 83 km cross-border high-voltage transmission line and 
a substation will be part of the overall transmission link on the Indonesian side to connect the 
West Kalimantan power grid to the power grid of neighboring Sarawak (Malaysia), thus enabling 
power exchange of about 230 megawatts (MW) between the two systems. ADB is preparing 
part of the transmission link on the Malaysian side as a separate nonsovereign loan financed 
project for the state-owned power utility in Sarawak, Malaysia.   
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The proposed project will reduce the cost of operating the power system in West 
Kalimantan. Oil is one of the most expensive power generation fuels accounting for a quarter of 
power  generation  in  Indonesia  and  all  power  generation  in  West  Kalimantan;  hence,  the 
average cost of power generation is about $0.25 per kilowatt-hour (kWh).4 Coal, an abundant 
local5 undeveloped resource is a substitute fuel for oil, with costs below $0.10/kWh.6 However, 
as developing these coal resources will take time (7–10 years), and West Kalimantan urgently 
needs additional electricity supply to meet growing needs, West Kalimantan considers access to 
cross-border power supply a priority to meet rising demand and at reduced costs. The proposed 
interconnection with Sarawak at a negotiated import price of $0.10 kWh will enable Indonesia's 
PLN to import 230 MW equivalent of power generation to the West Kalimantan grid by January 
2015. This will enable PLN to enhance its least-cost generation plan by combining hydropower 
imports  from  Sarawak  with  other  Indonesian  base-load  generation  from  oil  or  coal.  The 
proposed power imports may further reduce power generation costs in the future as Sarawak 
plans to develop more hydropower for an average power generation cost below $0.10/kWh.  
 
4.   The West Kalimantan system demand will grow to about 600 MW by 2020, from 
about 200 MW in 2012, and in the absence of the proposed interconnection, PLN plans to build 
new  coal  generation  to  switch  from  the  rented  oil  generators  that  PLN  now  uses.  The

2   
interconnection has always been an alternative option to meet long term system demand., The 
power utilities in the island of Borneo have been planning a 1,300 km long high-voltage power 
transmission link, the Trans Borneo Power Grid, to connect the West Kalimantan power grid 
across Sarawak, Brunei Darussalam, to Sabah and enable power exchanges between the 
BIMP-EAGA  countries.7  This  transmission  system  development  will  help  each  area  take 
advantage of the different power systems and different power generation mixes on the island of 
Borneo: West Kalimantan relies almost entirely on oil, Sarawak largely on hydropower, Brunei 
Darussalam on gas, and Sabah predominantly on diesel and fuel oil.  
 
5.  Reduced carbon footprint. Currently PLN relies entirely on oil for power generation in 
West Kalimantan. As PLN will eventually stop using expensive oil-based power generation, the 
overall carbon footprint of Borneo will be reduced. The power interconnection will benefit also 
both West Kalimantan and Sarawak directly. A base-load supply of 50 MW and about 180 MW 
for 6 hours a day will amount to about 650,000 megawatt-hours of import of cheaper power from 
Sarawak to West Kalimantan each year, at a negotiated import price of $0.10/kWh—annually 
PLN as the buyer will save about $100 million by avoiding oil generation and Sarawak as the 
seller  will earn about $33 million  with its low-cost power generation. This will also create 
opportunities for future power exports and sharing of system reserve margins between the two 
countries enabling further reduction of carbon footprint. 
 
6.  The proposed interconnection with Sarawak is of strategic importance to PLN. 
With  the  experience  of  this  interconnection,  PLN  plans  to  expand  its  power  exchange 
arrangements  with  its  neighbors,  although  the West  Kalimantan  system  is  relatively  small 
compared with the Indonesian system: in 2012, demand for power from the West Kalimantan 
system was about 200 MW compared with total Indonesian system demand of about 30,000 
MW; and the proposed 83 km long 275-kilovolt (kV) transmission line is relatively small—PLN 
plans to build about 50,000 km of transmission lines over the next 10 years, including 5,000 km 
of 275 kV lines.  
 
7.  Signed  power  exchange  agreement.  On  5  September  2012,  PLN  and  Syarikat 
SESCO confirmed their commitment to the project by signing the power exchange agreement 
(PEA) based on the term sheet signed on 18 July 2011. The PEA is for 20 years: the first phase 
covering the first 5 years has take-or-pay and take-and-pay prices.8 The second-phase duration 
could be for long term, medium term, or short term within a maximum capacity of 230 MW. The 
PEA covers purchase of about 50 MW of capacity as base load on a take-or-pay basis for 
5 years. In addition, PLN will be able to purchase another 180 MW of capacity as a take-and-
pay  contract.  Both  parties  secured  their  performance  obligations  with  bank  guarantees  of 
$35 million to each other. The parties agreed also to enter into an interconnection agreement 
before  30 June  2013.  The  PEA  includes  strict  milestone  schedules—(grid  completion:  31 
December 2014, and supply start: 1 January 2015) in order to avoid paying the $25,000-a-day 
penalty to each other. PLN has awarded contracts for four main packages and have signed 
these contracts under the approved advanced procurement action.  
  
8.  ADB’s continued support for regional cooperation. The project is aligned with ADB's 
energy  sector  assessment  strategy  and  road  map9  and  the  BIMP-EAGA  implementation 
                                                
7  BIMP-EAGA refers to the subregional initiative covering Brunei Darussalam–Indonesia–Malaysia–Philippines East 
ASEAN Growth Area (http://www.bimp-eaga.org/). 
8  Take-or-pay amounts are like capacity payments: payments for full amounts have to be made even if only a portion 
of the contract amount is consumed. Take-and-pay allows the buyer to pay only for the amounts used.  
9  Sector Assessment: Energy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

3 
blueprint,10 which made improving infrastructure facilities a priority and power interconnection a 
key strategic pillar. The project is also in line with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
(ASEAN) Connectivity Plan.11 ADB supports investment in strategic transmission assets that 
connects regions or countries to optimize power networks by removing transmission bottlenecks 
and transmitting cheaper power from one area to the other, thereby helping achieve overall 
regional socioeconomic and environmental improvement. This project is consistent with ADB’s 
country partnership strategy, 2012–201412 and country operations business plan, 2013–2014,13 
which support the government's economic growth target of 6.3%–6.8% per annum in 2010–
2014 and to reach 7% beyond 2014 despite protracted global recovery. Furthermore, ADB is 
now working with PLN on the Sumatra–Peninsular Malaysia power interconnection (250 km, 
500 kV, high-voltage direct current line for the sharing of power between Indonesia (Sumatra) 
and Peninsular Malaysia. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be sustainable power supply in West Kalimantan and the outcome will be 
the reduced cost of operating the power system in West Kalimantan.  
  
C.  Outputs 
10.  The project will have three outputs: (i) construction of about 83 km of 275 kV double-
circuit  transmission  line  between  Bengkayang  and  the  border  with  Sarawak,  with  a  new 
275/150/20 kV substation in Bengkayang; (ii) construction of about 145 km of 150 kV double-
circuit Bengkayang–Ngabang–Tayan distribution line,  with a new 150/250 kV substation in 
Ngabang and a four-line distribution feeder extension for the 150 kV Tayan substation and 
Bengkayang substation; and (iii) new connections to 8,000 households in West Kalimantan.  
  
11.  A large proportion of the population has no access to grid-connected electricity, and at 
any  given  time  a  large  number  of  customers  are  in  the  queue  for  connection  in  West 
Kalimantan. Because of power supply shortages and lack of funds for investing in low-voltage 
distribution,  PLN  is  unable  to  meet  the  demand  for  new  connections.  The  proposed  new 
household connections (output 3) will reduce the connection charges and connection time 
through a single initiative for the communities living between Bengkayang and Sarawak border. 
The connection charge varies from $35 to about $100 depending on the size of the connection 
(450–1,300 volt-amperes). About 8,000 households will also benefit from training on energy 
efficiency,  provision  of  energy-efficient  lighting,  and  improved  local  community  centers 
(hospitals and schools). With access to electricity, these households will have access to other 
economic opportunities, improve their livelihood, and stop using kerosene or oil lamps for 
lighting. This will contribute to ADB’s Energy for All Initiative to increase access to modern forms 
of energy.14 PLN will use its $2 million, a part of its counterpart funds, together with the $2 
million grant to support the necessary upgrade of low-voltage systems. ADB will work with PLN 
to determine the beneficiaries of output 3.15 The details will be finalized during inception of the 
project.

12.  The project has the potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and thereby may 
have prospects for carbon finance under the Clean Development Mechanism of the United 
Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change or any other successor mechanism. PLN 
and ADB will work together to undertake the necessary assessments based on future protocols 
to determine the eligibility of the project. Consultants recruited under this loan will also be 
exploring the possibility of selling carbon credits under some other international greenhouse gas 
emission reduction scheme.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
 
22.  ADB staff has reviewed the project preparatory studies and confirmed the technical 
project  design.  The  double-circuit  Mambong–Bengkayang  275  kV  transmission  line 
interconnection takes into account maintenance of the largest generating unit in  the West 
Kalimantan system and the need to import additional power from Sarawak to West Kalimantan 
to ensure the N-1 reliability contingency17 during operation. As most of the existing power plants 
in the West Kalimantan system will be retired by 2017, the power import to West Kalimantan as 
proposed is feasible under normal (N) and single contingency (N-1) conditions. Currently, PLN 
does not have an appropriate control center in Pontianak. Until the control center in Pontianak is 
ready, the 275 kV transmission line will be operated and controlled from Kuching. The technical 
teams of PLN and Sarawak Energy will have to agree on a standard operating practice.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
23.  Financial  and  economic  benefits  were  calculated  on  the  basis  of  imported  power, 
replacing expensive oil-fired power generation. The cost estimates are in constant 2012 prices. 
PLN’s recent project costs and consultants confirmation are the basis of these cost estimates.  
 
24.  The FIRR is 30%, based on a cash flow for 20 years, which is higher than the weighted 
average cost of capital of 2.1%, making the project financially viable. This project has a high 
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) because the financial benefits include, in addition to the 
benefit  of  wheeling  electricity,  the  direct  benefit  of  importing  power  at  a  lower  price  from 
Sarawak  enabling  PLN  and  avoid  expensive  power  generated  by  burning  oil  in  West 
Kalimantan.  The benefit calculation is based on a range of power purchase and off-take 
scenarios: the base-case scenario assumes that only 50 MW will be take-and-pay for off-peak 
time for the first 5 years, and only 50 MW will be purchased as base load after the first 5 years 
of contract at a 25% higher tariff. The high-case scenario assumes that 100 MW will be take-
and-pay for the first 5 years and same capacity will be purchased by PLN at a price 15% higher 
for the next 5 years, while the low-case scenario assumes that no take-and-pay and no power 
purchase will occur after the first 5 years. For the base case, the FIRR is 30% and the economic 
internal rate of return (EIRR) is 52%. The FIRR varies from 17.7% to 42.0% for the different 
scenarios. The EIRR ranges from 32% to 70%, and the net present value is $243 million (base 
case) over the life of the project.18  
 
C.  Governance 
 
25.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and PLN. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are  described  in  the  project  administration  manual.  To  ensure  transparency  and  good 
governance, PLN will publicly disclose on its website information on how loan proceeds are 
being used. For each procurement contract, PLN will disclose (i) the list of participating bidders, 
(ii) the name of the winning bidder, (iii) basic details on bidding procedures adopted, (iv) the 
amount of the contract awarded, (v) a list of goods and services purchased, and (vi) the 
intended and actual utilization of loan proceeds under each contract being awarded. ADB will

D.  Poverty and Social 
 
26.  Being  a  general-intervention  project  with  sustainability  and  regional  cooperation  as 
expected  impact,  the  poverty  reduction  channels  are  more  indirect.  However,  the  grant 
component will extend project benefits to the households in the project area. In addition to 
connecting  new  households,  it  will  improve  supply  reliability  (i.e.,  fewer  blackouts).  Local 
communities  will  also  be  able  to  work  in  project  construction  and  maintenance  activities. 
Industrial growth, especially in rubber factories, and increased trading activities with reliable 
power supply will create jobs, especially for low-income groups. The basic public services—
education, health, and water supply—will improve because of access to electricity. The project 
will benefit the minority households in the neighborhoods of the Benkawang substation to the 
border of Sarawak. There are no gender measures in the project. The project will not have any 
adverse impact on women and/or girls, or widen gender inequality. Due diligence did not 
highlight specific gender issues, as transmission projects are, by their nature, unlikely to provide 
opportunity for gender design; however, there will be direct and substantial benefits to women 
from better electricity supply. The benefits from electricity will accrue largely in the form of labor 
savings,  greater  social  interaction,  and  broader  options  for  work  and  other  activities.  The 
resettlement plans for the project include specific actions to ensure that women are included 
effectively  in  the  land  acquisition  process  (e.g.,  poor  women  and  households  headed  by 
women). A social impact assessment19 has been prepared to examine key aspects such as 
poverty, vulnerability, education, health, ethnicity, and gender.  
 
E.  Safeguards  
27.  Environment. In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project 
has  been  classified  as  category  B  for  environment,  requiring  the  preparation  of  an  initial 
environmental examination, which has been approved by PLN and ADB and disclosed on the 
ADB website on August 2011. The proposed transmission line will pass along existing roads 
and the transmission corridor is limited to areas affected by human presence with agriculture as 
the principal land use. Use of good international construction practices during implementation 
will  mitigate  some  of  the  temporary  impacts,  including,  vegetation  clearing,  soil  erosion, 
drainage,  effects  on  water  and  air  quality,  waste  management,  additional  demand  on 
infrastructure, hunting and fuel wood collection by workers, and occupational and community 
health and safety issues. Neither the 275 kV transmission line nor the 150 kV distribution line 
enters  any  protected  and  primary  forests,  wetlands,  or  areas  identified  as  having  special 
ecological significance or cultural heritage sites. The closest the 275 kV transmission line comes 
to a protected forest is about 2 km; north of Tayan, the 150 kV distribution line passes at a 
distance of 500–800 meters to the Gunung Condong protected forest, which will be designated 
as “no go” area to be strictly off-limit for all workers.  
 
28.  The final alignment will be fine-tuned to minimize entry into production forests and 
maximize  the  buffer  between  the  alignment  and  Gunung  Condong  protected  forest.  A 
comprehensive environmental management plan, with budget and responsibilities for mitigating 
measures and monitoring, both during construction and operation, includes occupational and 
community health and safety training, capacity building for PLN staff, and a clear structure for a 
                                                
19 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
grievance redress mechanism. There was adequate public consultation with stakeholders on 
environmental impacts and measures. 
 
29.  Social Safeguards. The project’s safeguard categorization is category B for involuntary 
resettlement and for indigenous people. PLN has paid one landowner for the 4 hectares of land 
needed for the Tayan substation in September 2012; and 5 landowners for the 6.6 hectares of 
land needed for the Magmagan substation in December 2012. Similarly, PLN has acquired and 
compensated for the land required for 89 of the 201 towers of the 275 kV transmission line and 
plans to complete the process for all remaining 112 towers  by the end of December 2013. PLN 
expects no delay or dispute in the process.  
 
30.  Since the impacts on indigenous peoples (customary communities) are mainly related to 
land  acquisition,  the  project  has  combined  resettlement  and  customary  communities 
development plans (resettlement plan) respectively for the 275 kV section from Benkayang to 
the Malaysian border and for the 150 kV section from Benkayang through Ngabang to Tayan. 
The resettlement plan for the 275 kV line is quite detailed, as it is based on an inventory of 
losses according to a concept design. For the 150 kV section, a concept design was not 
finalized and hence a separate resettlement plan was prepared. A more detailed resettlement 
plan will be prepared and disclosed before implementing the 150 kV distribution line. The two 
draft resettlement plans based on initial design—were submitted and approved by ADB in 2011 
and disclosed in July 2011. The resettlement plan for the 275 kV line was updated in April 2013, 
and the resettlement plan for the 150 kV line is now being updated following the final detailed 
design. The updated documents will incorporate a due diligence report for acquired land. Both 
draft resettlement plans20 include gender strategy and strategy for customary communities’ 
identity and cultural uniqueness. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
31.  With the signing of the PEA, the earlier perceived risks associated with the power import 
component are almost eliminated. The benefits of the project have been widely reported in the 
local media of both countries. Although there are significant penalties for both Sarawak Energy 
and  PLN  for  any  delays  under  the  PEA,  the  main  procurement  milestones  have  been 
completed, and the remaining risk is the delay in implementation. The risks and mitigating 
measures are summarized in Table 4 and are described in detail in the risk assessment and risk 
management plan.21

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
32.  The government and PLN have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
33.  The government and PLN have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
 
(i)  the loan of $49,500,000 to the Republic of Indonesia for the West Kalimantan 
Power Grid Strengthening Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with 
interest to be determined in accordance with ADB's London interbank offered 
rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; a term of 20 years, including a grace period 
of  3  years;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreements 
presented to the Board;  
 
(ii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  loan  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$49,500,000 to the Republic of Indonesia for the West Kalimantan Power Grid 
Strengthening Project to be provided by Agence Française de Développement, in 
accordance with the proposal set out under para. 15; and 
 
(iii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,000,000 to PT (Persero) Perusahaan Listrik Negara for the West Kalimantan 
Power  Grid  Strengthening  Project,  to  be  provided  by  the  Multi-Donor  Clean 
Energy Fund under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility.
